articles.headline: China’s Solar Dominance Presents Biden With an Ugly Dilemma
articles.snippet: President Biden’s vow to work with China on issues like climate change is clashing with his promise to defend human rights.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s vow to work with China on issues like climate change is clashing with his promise to defend human rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden has repeatedly pledged to work with China on issues like climate change while challenging Beijing on human rights and unfair trade practices.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Brad Plumer

articles.headline: Two Hollywood Executives, Awash in Awards and Admiration, Step Aside
articles.snippet: Steve Gilula and Nancy Utley have been at the top of Searchlight Pictures for more than two decades, shaping the film industry with hits like “12 Years a Slave,” “The Shape of Water” and “Nomadland.”
articles.abstract: Steve Gilula and Nancy Utley have been at the top of Searchlight Pictures for more than two decades, shaping the film industry with hits like “12 Years a Slave,” “The Shape of Water” and “Nomadland.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of corporate Hollywood’s most enduring double acts is calling it quits.

articles.headline: Apple’s New Devices Target Markets Led by Smaller Rivals
articles.snippet: The company also said it planned to release iPhone software next week with a privacy feature that worries many digital-advertising companies.
articles.abstract: The company also said it planned to release iPhone software next week with a privacy feature that worries many digital-advertising companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple unveiled a series of new products on Tuesday that showed how it continues to center its marketing pitch on consumer privacy, at the potential expense of other companies, while muscling into markets pioneered by much smaller competitors.

articles.headline: ‘We Matter’: A Moment of Catharsis After the Derek Chauvin Verdict
articles.snippet: People across the country reacted with a variety of emotions to the news of the former officer’s conviction on all charges in the killing of George Floyd.
articles.abstract: People across the country reacted with a variety of emotions to the news of the former officer’s conviction on all charges in the killing of George Floyd.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Outside the Cup Foods convenience store where George Floyd was killed last May, a woman nearly collapsed in tears upon hearing the guilty verdicts against Derek Chauvin, the police officer who killed Mr. Floyd.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Derek Chauvin Verdict Brings a Rare Rebuke of Police Misconduct
articles.snippet: A jury deliberated for just over 10 hours before pronouncing Mr. Chauvin guilty on all three charges: second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.
articles.abstract: A jury deliberated for just over 10 hours before pronouncing Mr. Chauvin guilty on all three charges: second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — A former police officer who pressed his knee into George Floyd’s neck until well past Mr. Floyd’s final breath was found guilty of murder on Tuesday in a case that shook the nation’s conscience and drew millions into the streets for the largest racial justice protests in generations.
articles.byline: By John Eligon, Tim Arango, Shaila Dewan and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: The Death of George Floyd Reignited a Movement. What Happens Now?
articles.snippet: Calls for racial justice touched nearly every aspect of American life on a scale that historians say has not happened since the civil rights movement of the 1960s.
articles.abstract: Calls for racial justice touched nearly every aspect of American life on a scale that historians say has not happened since the civil rights movement of the 1960s.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch, Amy Harmon, Sabrina Tavernise and Emily Badger

articles.headline: G.O.P. Bills Target Protesters (and Absolve Motorists Who Hit Them)
articles.snippet: As the nation reacts to the guilty verdict a jury handed to Derek Chauvin in the killing of George Floyd, Republican-led states are introducing punitive new measures governing protests.
articles.abstract: As the nation reacts to the guilty verdict a jury handed to Derek Chauvin in the killing of George Floyd, Republican-led states are introducing punitive new measures governing protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Nation Faces ‘Hand-to-Hand Combat’ to Get Reluctant Americans Vaccinated
articles.snippet: Half of American adults have received at least one shot of the coronavirus vaccine. Now comes the hard part: persuading the other half to get it.
articles.abstract: Half of American adults have received at least one shot of the coronavirus vaccine. Now comes the hard part: persuading the other half to get it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Now that President Biden has met his goal to have all adults eligible for the coronavirus vaccine, health officials around the country are hitting what appears to be a soft ceiling: More than half the nation’s adults have received at least one dose, but it is going to take hard work — and some creative changes in strategy — to convince the rest.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Welcome to the YOLO Economy
articles.snippet: Burned out and flush with savings, some workers are quitting stable jobs in search of postpandemic adventure.
articles.abstract: Burned out and flush with savings, some workers are quitting stable jobs in search of postpandemic adventure.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Europe Proposes Strict Rules for Artificial Intelligence
articles.snippet: The regulations would have far-reaching implications for tech firms like Amazon, Google, Facebook and Microsoft, which have poured resources into developing the technology.
articles.abstract: The regulations would have far-reaching implications for tech firms like Amazon, Google, Facebook and Microsoft, which have poured resources into developing the technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union unveiled strict regulations on Wednesday to govern the use of artificial intelligence, a first-of-its-kind policy that outlines how companies and governments can use a technology seen as one of the most significant, but ethically fraught, scientific breakthroughs in recent memory.

articles.headline: Manic Markets, Imploding Funds: Wall Street’s New Top Cop Has a Full Plate
articles.snippet: Gary Gensler, the new S.E.C. chairman, wants to improve corporate disclosure and regulate digital assets better. But a lot awaits him already.
articles.abstract: Gary Gensler, the new S.E.C. chairman, wants to improve corporate disclosure and regulate digital assets better. But a lot awaits him already.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s new watchdog, Gary Gensler, is coming to the job with an ambitious agenda that includes taking a hard look at how to regulate digital currencies and requiring more environmental disclosures of companies. But the market may already be dictating some of the agenda for Mr. Gensler.

articles.headline: An E.V. Start-Up Backed by UPS Does Away With the Assembly Line
articles.snippet: Arrival, a developer of electric vans and buses, says it has come up with a cheaper way to build vehicles in small factories. But can it deliver on that promise?
articles.abstract: Arrival, a developer of electric vans and buses, says it has come up with a cheaper way to build vehicles in small factories. But can it deliver on that promise?
articles.lead_paragraph: A small electric vehicle company backed by UPS wants to replace the assembly lines automakers have used for more than a century with something radically different — small factories employing a few hundred workers.
